title: How does a singer get a recording contract with a record label? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s really no formula, any more. Labels don’t tend to want a ton of artists they need to invest time and money developing so they typically gravitate towards those who already have established fans, some EPs or albums recorded, and a fairly efficiently running career already. Those who can draw a decent crowd to a show in a number of cities, sell merch, and prove that they have a real-world following and not just social media numbers that present well. 200k+ Twitter followers aren’t very useful if they don’t support an artist’s career, buy music and merch, and invest real time and money in the act. Labels (typically) want what seem to be pretty successful acts by most people’s estimations. Why do I keep using the word typically? Because there are always going to be exceptions.

Do you have a demo for me? I suggest you to watch the television series “Vinyl” on HBO. I sugest you to watch the television series “Empire” currently available on Hulu. It is very difficult to get a recording contract with a record label in this day and age.
